'Superstorm' Sandy

More than 350,000 without power in Mass.

Sandy batters region

Coastal communities braced for flooding from wind-whipped waves at the next high tide tonight. (Boston Globe)

Mammoth storm shutters New York City

The threat of a record storm surge inundating Manhattan prompted officials to close the mass transit system. (AP)

Weather Wisdom

Historic damage in parts of mid-Atlantic

The greatest threat for damage overnight for the region will be the high tide around midnight. writes meteorologist David Epstein. (Boston.com)

Complete coverage from the BDC Storm Center
Lower Manhattan went dark during the hybrid storm as authorities warned that New York City and Long Island could get the worst of the storm surge. Bebeto Matthews/AP
Waves crashed on the shore along Nahant Road in Nahant on Oct. 29. Aram Boghosian For The Boston Globe
A man secured the lines on a boat in Eel Pond in Woods Hole on Oct. 29. Bill Greene/Globe Staff
As Hurricane Sandy made it way to shore, thrill seekers, including Sandy O'Connor of Manchester, N.H., left, take on the high tide at Hampton Beach in Hampton, N.H., on Oct. 29. Cheryl Senter For The Boston Globe
Waves crashed over homes on Turner Road in Scituate and slammed into a seawall on Oct. 29. David L Ryan/Globe Staff
A sailboat ripped away from its mooring rested in Quincy Bay near the causeway to East Squantum Street in Quincy at high tide on Oct. 29. Stan Grossfeld/Globe Staff
Rough surf of the Atlantic Ocean broke over the dunes this morning in Cape May, N.J., as high tide and Hurricane Sandy began to arrive. AP Photo
Waves crashed against a seawall in Scituate this morning before high tide, which comes at noon. David L. Ryan / Globe Staff
Strong, steady winds from Hurricane Sandy blew through Hatteras Island, N.C., early this morning. AP Photo
Mark Palazzolo, owner of a bait and tackle shop on the Manasquan Inlet in Point Pleasant Beach, N.J., sat next to wood he has used to board up his business in previous major storms. AP Photo
A woman took a photo on the boardwalk at Rockaway Beach in the Queens borough of New York City. Sandy could be the biggest storm to hit the United States mainland when it comes ashore tonight. Reuters Photo

State wants pharmacist
to resign as a regulator

The lead pharmacist of a sister company to the pharmacy at the center of the meningitis outbreak has been asked to resign from the state board that oversees pharmacies.
Opinion | Christopher L. Gasper

Patriots still searching for identity

Sherlock Holmes would have a tough time figuring out this year’s Patriots, who reached the halfway mark at 5-3.

Late moderate turn carrying Romney

The more moderate tone and style Mitt Romney adopted in the presidential election’s closing weeks have boosted his once-flagging campaign.
Opinion | JULIETTE KAYYEM

US view of Cuba is stuck in 1960s

The Cuban Missile Crisis ended 50 years ago Sunday. But since that time, the relationship between the United States and Cuba has remained static.

Focus of Windows 8 is touch

Windows 8 is Microsoft’s most radical upgrade to Windows since the 1990s. To master it, users must learn new ways to interact with their computers.

Living with back pain

Most treatments from painkillers to physical therapy to surgery aren’t permanent solutions for the pain, which has led to a rise in rehab programs.

Giving back to the electric grid

Boston will embark on a program to build energy-positive housing — homes that produce more electric power than they consume.

Business

Storm will keep financial markets closed Tuesday

Stock trading will be closed in the US for a second day Tuesday as Hurricane Sandy bears down on the East Coast. Bond trading will also be closed.

Everyday is Halloween

During a big storm, people feel compelled to flock to the store for milk, eggs, and other deemed essentials. That being said, with the treat of Halloween and trick of Hurricane Sandy upon us -- Straight Up stocks up on candy, whiskey, and old horror movies.
